review_blob: On tap at the Ginger Man, NYC. Very light in texture, with a distinctly "Japanese"/sake flavour likely owing to possible aging in sake casks, or some other involvement. Was the highlight of a day out beer tasting in the City. Probably ridiculously expensive in bottles.
beer_name: Hitachino Nest New Year Celebration Ale

review_blob: On tap at the brewery, and out of bottles/kegs locally. A great session IPA, and is often fairly inexpensive. Easy to drink several of them..

Ive had it on draft, from a bomber, growler and minikeg - probably my favorite widely distributed IPA. Citrussy bitterness is the key flavor, while the texture has enough substance that you cant get bored. Took out a half of the minikeg in a night no problem, and would call this my very favorite beer if the price wasnt so damn high. You get what you pay for, though.

On tap somewhere in Boston, cant remember where. Cool idea that its Boston-only (and only on draft.) Really enjoyable red; definitely a session style ale. A much, much better alternative to Killians, etc. If its still around when I get back to Boston, Ill be having a few of these.

Out of a seasonal mixpack. Very similar to the Summer Ale, with more lemons and less "grains of paradise". Would be hard to drink more than one due to high lemon content. Sour enough  to detect on the tongue, with a similar reaction as straight lemon juice (albeit less intense).
Out of a bottle from a seasonal mixpack. Thin with odd flavours on the finish, like they used the mash twice.
From a bottle out of seasonal mixpack. Flavorful, but concentrated in that way that most sam adams brews are (specifically the octoberfest). Very similar to Browns Brewings pilsner (Troy NY).

From a bomber. Fantastic IPA colour, good aroma, but extremely light on taste. Definitely not PNW-style IPA, and I dont have enough knowledge of the British style to make a determination. Strong hop finish. Was not satisfied.
From a 12oz. Definitely has the character of an Imperial IPA, but not quite as big as others in the style, or even other styles. Good mid-palate but finish too strong. A little disappointing.

From a 12oz. Definitely fruity; a blackberry lager if anything - not really any wit character to it besides on texture. Artificial-tasting blackberry flavour dominates everything. Not offensive, but would rather buy/drink other things.

From a 12oz. Smelled like feet and tasted like bacon; I am surprised to see such positive reviews here. It is possible I got a bad bottle, but I dont know what would make such a terrible flavour, and it was within date. First drain pour Ive had in a while.
beer_name: Samuel Adams Imperial Series Imperial Stout

review_blob: On tap at Rock Cafe in Springfield, MA. Appearance and flavour are indistinct; a hint of the style comes through in the taste but its otherwise pretty much your standard better-than-usual-macro ale, more like a pale ale than a white ale.

Widely available, on tap and in bottle. A good, drinkable fall/winter beer, but would probably be difficult/undesirable to drink more than one at a time. I generally have one on tap near the start of Winter and thats it. Not a favourite.
From a 12oz and on tap. As others have said, its a decent Oktoberfest-style brew. A bit thin perhaps, but a nice seasonal thats not overpoweringly flavoured.

From a 12oz. Did you eat your Wheaties today? No? Thats okay, have this beer for breakfast. Extremely wheaty texture and flavour, so much so thats thats pretty much the only flavour and texture in town. I didnt enjoy it.

From a 12oz. Smells OK.. could be alright.. then, yikes. Cranberry acidity and "beer flavour" assail the mouth. Couldnt drink the whole thing. Do not want, thats for sure. Im a Sam supporter more often than not but this goes up with Cherry Wheat as the worst beer they make.
On tap at Theodores, Springfield MA. A good pale ale, not too complex and not near IPA status.. strange presence of strawberry/raspberry in the mid to back palate.. Good though and would drink again.
beer_name: Berkshire Steel Rail Extra Pale Ale

review_blob: On tap at the Sheraton Hotel bar in Springfield, MA. Good beer overall, but surprisingly non-IPA.. more like an "American Strong Ale." More surprising is that it was only 5.5%..
beer_name: Berkshire Lost Sailor India Pale Ale

review_blob: From a 24oz bottle. In most ways your typical lager, but it does have at least a little character. A far superior choice than most American macros (Bud, Miller etc).

Out of a bomber. Smells like wheat beer, tastes like wheat beer with only the slightest hint of what could be maple anything. Finish is almost soapy or chalky, followed by alcohol. Very disappointing out of Harpoon.
beer_name: Harpoon 100 Barrel Series #26 - Catamount Maple Wheat

review_blob: On tap at Ginger Man, NYC. A good, balanced, tasty, easy-drinking cider right up until the finish, which is probably the driest of any cider Ive ever had. I understand its "brut, but it would be hard to get through a pint of it without needing IV fluids.
beer_name: Etienne Dupont Cidre Bouch Brut de Normandie

review_blob: On tap at the Ginger Man, NYC. Very dark; seemed undercarbonated as most beers at this establishment did. Does not have the typical Unibroue flavour or alcohol character, for better or worse. Mellow to a fault. Would be a good beer for a dark, rainy fall night.

On tap at the Ginger Man, NYC. Very dark - tastes like what might happen if you ran a good beer through the Jack Daniels distillery. Im no fan of weak, wimpy beers but drinking a pint of this would be next to impossible for me. Obvious alcohol character - not at all surprised to see the 12%. If you like bourbon, this is a match made in heaven for you.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2009
On tap at the Ginger Man. Good, balanced IPA, but lacking a little oomph all the way around. The DFH 90 minute is a much better brew all around. As another rater said its DFH with "training wheels."

On tap at the Ginger Man, NYC. Definitely spicy with almost a rum drink look and taste. Perhaps undercarbonated (or an underpressure keg).. a good "food" beer but I couldnt imagine how long it would take me to drink a whole pint.

On tap at the Ginger Man in NYC. Good Tripel, but with a strong Irish/Scotch whiskey character, almost as if it was aged in pre-used oak. Would be curious to try this in a bottle and see how it compared.
On tap at Rattle n Hum. Good DIPA, very much like Stones regular IPA, just stronger hopping. Slightly over-bitter/off finish.
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2010
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2010
beer_name: Samuel Adams Imperial Series Imperial White

review_blob: In a bottle from a mixpack (!). Extremely disappointing; odd flavour and lack of body followed by an undisguised alcohol finish. Avoid.
In a bottle from a mixpack. Its extremely light, wimpy ale. Refreshing, sure, but for what a Flying Dog mixpack costs it should be better.
beer_name: Flying Dog Tire Bite Golden Ale

review_blob: In a bottle from a mixpack. Good at first blush, but comes forth with a medicinal/bittery mid- to back palate. Ill admit Im not sure what "Colorado-style" IPA entails, entirely, but as a PNW supremacist it doesnt do it for me.
beer_name: Flying Dog Snake Dog IPA (2008 and later)

review_blob: UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009

Had it on tap at Rattle n Hum in NYC. Strikes me as "tripel light" - I am surprised to read other RBers ratings! Probably the most "reserved", lightly flavoured tripel Ive ever had.. which is not a good thing in my opinion. Would definitely drink again, but wish there was just more there.
Had it on tap at the brewery. Tasted like pennies, metallic all around. Definitely not one of my favourites.
Had it on tap at both the brewery and Rattle n Hum in NYC. Very definite contender for best PNW-style IPA that Ive ever had. I dont know how much more I can say.

Had it on tap at BXL Cafe, Manhattan. Served in its own particular glassware with wooden handle/device. Smells like a Belgian, looks like a Belgian, odd bitter and sourness with a Belgian finish. Definitely has its own character, but not one I cared for.

Had it on tap at the brewery. Its a blueberry wheat beer - including the usual synthetic-ish blueberry taste. Not the best or worst Ive ever had, and it goes down easy. Depending on the day, it can be the best thing on tap there (take that as you will)

Had it on tap at the brewery. Reminded me a lot of holiday ales from Seattle - Maritime Pacifics Jolly Roger to be specific. High alcohol dominates - tastes higher than it actually is (more like barleywine-level).
Had it on tap at the brewery. Light all around, generally unimpressive. I get that thats what a Koelsch generally is, but you are better off with anything else they have on tap.
Had it on tap at the brewery. Solid stout - not my favourite style so not much more to say about it.
Had it on tap at the brewery. An OK IPA, but doesnt quite run on all cylinders.. needs a little more oomph all the way around - body, taste, finish.

Had it on tap at the brewery. An excellently balanced ale - not so weak that you wouldnt want to drink it, but not so overbearing that it wears on you. Recommended for those that might want an "introductory Rye".
In my opinion Ommegangs worst offering - and their most expensive. Dark chocolate and cherries, but in a strange way.
My least favourite of the Belgian styles; not Ommegangs strongest offering. A good choice for real beer if on tap with poor alternatives.
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2010
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2009

From a 12oz, contract brewed in Saratoga (local brewery). Great colour; was one of three blueberry brews tasted consecutively and was the best of the bunch. Taste was not unidimensional as in many other examples of the type. If blueberry is your thing and want a more refined experience than some other brews out there, this is a good one. Side note: this one was notched "best before" the month which it was consumed.

From a 12oz. Yellow with white foam. Not much to comment - slight blueberry aroma, not much blueberry taste. Not much at all to it tastewise actually. Mid-tongue bitterness that stays with you. Do not want.
beer_name: Sea Dog Wild Blueberry Wheat Ale
